  1. Converting the following proposition into CNF:

$$ P = p_1 \wedge \neg (p_2 \vee p_3) \vee \neg p_4 $$

è½¬æ¢ä¸ºNNF

$$ \begin{align*} F = C(P) &= C(p_1 \wedge \neg (p_2 \vee p_3) \vee \neg p_4) \\\
&= C(p_1) \wedge C(\neg(p_2 \vee p_3)) \vee C(\neg p_4) \\\
&= p_1 \wedge C(\neg (p_2 \vee p_3)) \vee \neg p_4 \\\
&= p_1 \wedge (C(\neg p_2) \wedge C(\neg p_3)) \vee \neg p_4 \\\
&= p_1 \wedge (\neg p_2 \wedge \neg p_3) \vee \neg p_4 \\\
&= p_1 \wedge \neg p_2 \wedge \neg p_3 \vee \neg p_4 \end{align*}$$

è½¬æ¢ä¸º CNF

$$ \begin{align*} C(F) &= C((p_1 \wedge \neg p_2 \wedge \neg p_3) \vee \neg p_4) \\\
&= D(C(p_1 \wedge \neg p_2 \wedge \neg p_3), C(\neg p_4)) \\\
&= D(C(p_1) \wedge C(\neg p_2) \wedge C(\neg p_3), \neg p_4) \\\
&= D(p_1 \wedge \neg p_2 \wedge \neg p_3, \neg p_4) \\\
&= D(p_1, \neg p_4) \wedge D(\neg p_2, \neg p_4) \wedge D(\neg p_3, \neg p_4) \\\
&= (p_1 \vee \neg p_4) \wedge (\neg p_2 \vee \neg p_4) \wedge (\neg p_3 \vee \neg p_4) \end{align*}$$

int power3(int in) {

With EUF, we can prove these two algorithms are equivalent by proving this proposition is valid:

P2 = And(out_b == f(f(inp, inp), inp))

$$\begin{align*} C(F) &= C(\neg (p \to (q \wedge (\neg p \to q)))) \\\

$$\begin{align*} C(F) &= C(\neg (\neg p \vee (q \wedge (\neg \neg p \vee q)))) \\\
&= C(\neg (\neg p)) \wedge C(\neg (q \wedge (\neg \neg p \vee q))) \\\
&= p \wedge (C(\neg q) \vee C(\neg (\neg \neg p \vee q))) \\\
&= p \wedge (\neg q \vee (C(\neg \neg \neg p) \wedge C(\neg q))) \\\

$$\begin{align*} C(F) &= C(p \wedge (\neg q \vee (\neg p \wedge \neg q))) \\\
&= C(p) \wedge C(\neg q \vee (\neg p \wedge \neg q)) \\\
&= p \wedge (D(C(\neg q), C(\neg p \wedge \neg q))) \\\
&= p \wedge (D(\neg q, C(\neg p \wedge \neg q))) \\\
&= p \wedge (D(\neg q, \neg p \wedge \neg q)) \\\
&= p \wedge (D(\neg q, \neg p) \wedge D(\neg q, \neg q)) \\\
&= p \wedge (\neg q \vee \neg p) \wedge (\neg q \vee \neg q) \\\
&= p \wedge (\neg q \vee \neg p) \wedge \neg q \end{align*}$$

DPLL(F) {
    newF = BCP(F)
    if(newF == TRUE)
        return sat;
    if(newF == FALSE)

    x = select_var(newF);
    if(DPLL(newF[x -> TRUE]))

    return DPLL(newF[x -> FALSE])
}

The BCP() method stands for Boolean Constraint Propagation, which is based on unit resolution. Unit resolution deals with one unit clause, which must be p or ~p, and one clause contains the negation of the unit clause.

Suppose we call the function DPLL() with the following proposition F:

$$ F = (\neg p_1 \vee p_3) \wedge (\neg p_2 \vee p_3 \vee p_4) \wedge (p_1 \vee \neg p_3 \vee \neg p_4) \wedge (p_1) $$

decideEquality() {
    for (each "x = y") {
        setx = find(x);
        sety = find(y);
        union(setx, sety);
    }
    while (stillChanging) {  // closure
        if ("s1 = t1", ..., "sn = tn") {
            union(f(s1, ..., sn), f(t1, ..., tn));
        }
    }
    for (each "x != y") {
        setx = find(x);
        sety = find(y);
        if(setx == sety)
            return UNSAT;
    }
    return SAT;
}

int power3(int in) {
    int i, out_a;
    out_a = in;
    for(i = 0; i < 2; i++)

}

int power3_new(int in) {
    int out_b;
    out_b = (in*in)*in;

}

$$f(P) = \begin{cases} f(Q) \cup f(R), &\text{if} \ \ P = Q \wedge R \ | \ Q \vee R \ | \ Q \to R \\\ \\ f(Q) - \lbrace x \rbrace, &\text{if} \ \ P = \forall x.\ Q \ | \ \exists x.\ Q \\\ \\

\phi, &\text{if} \ \ E = c \\\ \\

ç¤ºä¾‹

$ Ex. \quad A = \exists x.\ (P(x,\ y) \vee \forall y.\ Q(x,\ y) \to R(x,\ z))$

è¿‡ç¨‹å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

$$ \begin{align*} f(A) &= f(\exists x.\ (P(x,\ y) \vee \forall y.\ Q(x,\ y) \to R(x,\ z))) \\\
&= f(P(x,\ y) \vee \forall y.\ Q(x,\ y) \to R(x,\ z)) - \lbrace x \rbrace \\\
&= f(P(x,\ y) \vee \forall y.\ Q(x,\ y)) \cup f(R(x,\ z)) - \lbrace x \rbrace \\\
&= f(P(x,\ y)) \cup f(\forall y.\ Q(x,\ y)) \cup \lbrace x,\ z \rbrace - \lbrace x \rbrace \\\
&= \lbrace x,\ y \rbrace \cup (f(Q(x,\ y)) - \lbrace y \rbrace) \cup \lbrace x,\ z \rbrace - \lbrace x \rbrace \\\
&= \lbrace x,\ y \rbrace \cup (\lbrace x,\ y \rbrace - \lbrace y \rbrace) \cup \lbrace x,\ z \rbrace - \lbrace x \rbrace \\\
&= \lbrace x,\ y \rbrace \cup \lbrace x \rbrace \cup \lbrace x,\ z \rbrace - \lbrace x \rbrace \\\
&= \lbrace x,\ y,\ z \rbrace - \lbrace x \rbrace \\\
&= \lbrace y,\ z \rbrace \end{align*} $$

ç»Ÿè®¡ç»‘å®šå˜é‡çš„ç®—æ³•

$$ f(P) = \begin{cases} \phi, &\text{if} \ \ P = r(E_1, \ \dots, \ E_n) \\\ \\
\phi, &\text{if} \ \ P = \top \ | \ \bot \\\ \\
f(R) \cup f(Q) &\text{if} \ \ P = Q \wedge R \ | \ Q \vee R \ | \ Q \to R \\\ \\
\lbrace x \rbrace \cup f(R) &\text{if} \ \ P = \forall x.\ R \ | \ \exists x.\ R \end{cases} $$

ç¤ºä¾‹

$ Ex. \quad A = \exists x.\ (P(x,\ y) \vee \forall y.\ Q(x,\ y) \to R(x,\ z))$

è¿‡ç¨‹å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

$$ \begin{align*} f(A) &= f(\exists x.\ (P(x,\ y) \vee \forall y.\ Q(x,\ y) \to R(x,\ z))) \\\
&= \lbrace x \rbrace \cup f(P(x,\ y) \vee \forall y.\ Q(x,\ y) \to R(x,\ z)) \\\
&= \lbrace x \rbrace \cup f(P(x,\ y) \vee \forall y.\ Q(x,\ y)) \cup f(R(x,\ z)) \\\
&= \lbrace x \rbrace \cup f(P(x,\ y)) \cup f(\forall y.\ Q(x,\ y)) \cup \lbrace \rbrace \\\
&= \lbrace x \rbrace \cup \lbrace \rbrace \cup f(\forall y.\ Q(x,\ y)) \cup \lbrace \rbrace \\\
&= \lbrace x \rbrace \cup \lbrace \rbrace \cup \lbrace y \rbrace \cup f(Q(x,\ y)) \cup \lbrace \rbrace \\\
&= \lbrace x \rbrace \cup \lbrace \rbrace \cup \lbrace y \rbrace \cup \lbrace \rbrace \cup \lbrace \rbrace \\\
&= \lbrace x,\ y \rbrace \end{align*} $$

$$ P[x \mapsto E] = \begin{cases} E, &\text{if} \ \ P = x \\\ \\
y, &\text{if} \ \ P = y \ \text{and} \ y \neq x \\\ \\
f(E_1[x \mapsto E], \ \dots, \ E_n[x \mapsto E]) &\text{if} \ \ P = f(E_1,\ \dots,\ E_n) \\\ \\
R(E_1[x \mapsto E], \ \dots, \ E_n[x \mapsto E]) &\text{if} \ \ P = R(E_1,\ \dots,\ E_n) \\\ \\
Q[x \mapsto E] \vee R[x \mapsto E], &\text{if} \ \ P = Q \vee R \\\ \\
Q[x \mapsto E] \wedge R[x \mapsto E], &\text{if} \ \ P = Q \wedge R \\\ \\
Q[x \mapsto E] \to R[x \mapsto E], &\text{if} \ \ P = Q \to R \\\ \\
\forall x.\ Q, &\text{if} \ \ P = \forall x.\ Q \\\ \\
\forall y.\ (Q[x \mapsto E]), &\text{if} \ \ P = \forall y.\ Q \\\ \\
\exists x.\ Q, &\text{if} \ \ P = \exists x.\ Q \\\ \\
\exists y.\ (Q[x \mapsto E]), &\text{if} \ \ P = \exists y.\ Q \end{cases} $$

ç¤ºä¾‹

$ Ex 1. $ è®¾å­˜åœ¨å‘½é¢˜ $$ F = \exists x.\ (P(y,\ x) \wedge P(y,\ z)) $$ æœ‰ä¸‹åˆ—æ›¿æ¢è§„åˆ™ $$ F[x \mapsto R(x,\ y)] $$ ç»“æœä¸ºï¼Ÿ

è§£ï¼šå› ä¸º $x$ æ˜¯ç»‘å®šå˜é‡ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œæ›¿æ¢ä¹‹åçš„ç»“æœä¸å˜ã€‚

$ Ex 2. $ è®¾å­˜åœ¨å‘½é¢˜ $$ F = \exists x.\ (P(y,\ x) \wedge \forall y.\ (\neg Q(y,\ x)) \vee P(y,\ z)) $$ ç»™å‡ºä½¿ç”¨æ›¿æ¢è§„åˆ™ $$ F[y \mapsto x] $$ çš„ç»“æœã€‚

è§£ï¼šæ›¿æ¢è¿‡ç¨‹å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼Œ

$$ \begin{align*} F[y \mapsto x] &= (\exists x.\ (P(y,\ x) \wedge \forall y.\ (\neg Q(y,\ x)) \vee P(y,\ z)))[y \mapsto x] \\\

$$\begin{align*} C(p) &= p \\\ C(\neg p) &= \neg p \\\ C(P \wedge Q) &= C(P) \wedge C(Q) \\\ C(P \vee Q) &= C(P) \vee C(Q) \\\ C(P \to Q) &= \neg C(P) \vee C(Q) \end{align*}$$
